repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Science Research and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. Some of the key lessons learned
            include: a) It is important that intermediate products from
            research be applied by the productive sector, which requires
            a more demand-driven approach, in turn requiring a much
            increased participation by the private sector. b)
            Cooperation agreements between well established and emerging
            groups, as well as among groups from more-advanced and
            less-advanced regions should be encouraged. c) Collaborative
            use of sophisticated equipment and cost recovery through
            user and service charges should be encouraged to keep
            technology support infrastructure from rapidly becoming
            outdated, and training of high-level technicians and the
            development of good career prospects for them should be
            emphasized. d) Interchanges with foreign centers of
            excellence should be increased and the use of international
            peer reviewers encouraged. e) Performance indicators and an
            efficient Management Information System should be developed.
            f) Executing agencies should control the details of the way
            funds are allocated. G) Bank procurement procedures should
            respond to the special needs of scientific research
            projects. H) The appointment of independent advisory groups
            of prominent national and international professionals
            provide a valuable contribution to strategy setting,
            evaluation of results, and feedback to the Borrower and to
            the Bank.

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Science Research and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            continue to strengthen research capacity in key scientific
            and support areas, including human resources development,
            and to consolidate institutional reforms.  The project also
            seeks to improve science sector management and encourage
            policies designed to improve the economic environment for
            technological innovation.  The project finances the purchase
            of equipment, local and overseas training, research
            expenses, consultant services, information services,
            publications, and monitoring and evaluation for an estimated
            900 training and research programs in the areas currently
            being supported under the Support Program for Scientific and
            Technological Development I (PADCT) as well as in the two
            areas of new materials and environmental science.  In
            addition, the project supports a policy study which will
            review issues related to the long term role of science and
            technology in Brazil's economic development and a study
            on the productivity and international competitiveness of
            Brazilian industry.
